title: To Copy or Not to Copy
narrative:
In this specification we cover the behaviour of tensors with respect to their copy methods. There are to main ways to copy a tensor:
1. .shallowCopy()
2. .deepCopy()

The first method creates a new tensor with the same underlying data array as the original tensor.
The second method on the other hand creates a new tensor with a new data array.

The first method is the most efficient, but it is not as safe as the second method.
The second method is the most safe, but it is not as efficient.

Besides these 2 main requirements, there are als some corner cases with respect to the components of a tensor (like for example its computation graph) which will be covered in this specification as well.

features.id: A deep copy of a tensor is also a deep copy of the underlying data array.

blocks.text: A tensor of ints with shape (2, 3).
The underlying data array is as expected.
code: t.mut.data.get() == [1, 2, -9, 8, 3, -2] // It's unsafe because it exposes mutable parts of the tensor!

blocks.text: We create a deep copy of the tensor.
The copy is not the same instance as the original tensor.
code: deep !== t // It's not the same instance!

blocks.text: The shape and underlying data array are equal to the original tensor but the data is not identical.
code: deep.mut.data.get() == t.mut.data.get() // The tensors share the same values!
deep.mut.data.get() !== t.mut.data.get() // ...but they are not the same array!
(0..<t.size).every({ int i -> deep.at(i) == t.at(i) }) // The values are the same!

features.id: A shallow copy of a tensor will be flagged as such. [0]

blocks.text: The tensor we will use for copying is not flagged as a shallow copy.
We create a shallow copy of the tensor.
The copy is not the same instance as the original tensor.
code: shallow !== t // It's not the same instance!

blocks.text: The shape and underlying data array are equal to the original tensor but the data is not identical.
code: shallow.mut.data.get() == t.mut.data.get() // The tensors share the same values...
shallow.mut.data.get() === t.mut.data.get() // ...as well as the same array!
shallow.mut.data === t.mut.data // In fact, their data container is the same instance.
(0..<t.size).every({ int i -> shallow.at(i) == t.at(i) }) // The values are the same!

blocks.text: The shallow copy is flagged as such.
Because shallow copies are merely "fully slices" we expect this flag to be set as well.
The inverse property is false:

Because shallow copies are merely "fully slices" we expect this flag to be set as well.
The inverse property is false:

The copy is not the same instance as the original tensor.
code: shallow !== t // It's not the same instance!

code: shallow.mut.data.get() == t.mut.data.get() // The tensors share the same values...
shallow.mut.data.get() === t.mut.data.get() // ...as well as the same array!
shallow.mut.data === t.mut.data // In fact, their data container is the same instance.

blocks.text: The shallow copy is flagged as such.
Because shallow copies are merely "fully slices" we expect this flag to be set as well.
The inverse property is false:

features.id: A deep copy of a slice tensor is also a deep copy of the underlying data array.

blocks.text: A slice of ints with shape (2, 2) sliced in-place from a tensor of shape (3, 3).
The underlying items and data array is as expected.
code: s.mut.data.get() == [1, 2, -9, 8, 3, -2, 1, 2, -9] // It's unsafe because it exposes mutable parts of the tensor!

blocks.text: We create a deep copy of the tensor.
The copy is not the same instance as the original tensor.
code: deep !== s // It's not the same instance!

blocks.text: The underlying items and data array are as expected.
code: deep.mut.data.get() == [2, -9, 3, -2] // It's unsafe because it exposes mutable parts of the tensor!

blocks.text: The slice and the copy have the same shape.
code: deep.items == s.items // The tensors share the same values!
deep.items !== s.items // The tensors share the same values!
deep.mut.data.get() !== s.mut.data.get() // The tensors share the same values!
deep.mut.data.get() !== s.mut.data.get() // ...but they are not the same array!

blocks.text: We verify that they share the same ints through the "every" method.
code: (0..<s.size).every({ int i -> deep.at(i) == s.at(i) }) // The values are the same!

features.id: A shallow copy will share the same underlying data as its original tensor. [0]

blocks.text: A tensor of ints with shape (2, 3).
The underlying data array is as expected.
code: t.mut.data.get() == [1, 2, -9, 8, 3, -2] // It's unsafe because it exposes mutable parts of the tensor!

blocks.text: We create a shallow copy of the tensor.
The copy is not the same instance as the original tensor.
code: shallow !== t // It's not the same instance!
shallow.mut.data.get() == t.mut.data.get() // The tensors share the same values!
shallow.mut.data.get() === t.mut.data.get() // The tensors share the exact same data array!

blocks.text: We verify that they share the same ints through the "every" method.
code: (0..<t.size).every({ int i -> shallow.at(i) == t.at(i) }) // The values are the same!

features.id: A shallow copy will share the same underlying data as its original tensor. [1]

blocks.text: A tensor of ints with shape (2, 3).

code: t.mut.data.get() == [1, 2, -9, 8, 3, -2] // It's unsafe because it exposes mutable parts of the tensor!

blocks.text: We create a shallow copy of the tensor.
The copy is not the same instance as the original tensor.
code: shallow !== t // It's not the same instance!
shallow.mut.data.get() == t.mut.data.get() // The tensors share the same values!
shallow.mut.data.get() === t.mut.data.get() // The tensors share the exact same data array!

blocks.text: We verify that they share the same ints through the "every" method.
code: (0..<t.size).every({ int i -> shallow.at(i) == t.at(i) }) // The values are the same!

features.id: We can deep copy various types of tensors. [0]

blocks.text: A simple vector tensor which we are going to copy.
A slice of the tensor, which we should also be able to deep copy.
The copy is not the same instance as the original tensor.
code: deep !== t // It's not the same instance!
deepSlice !== s // It's not the same instance!

blocks.text: The shape and underlying data array are equal to the original tensor but the data is not identical.
code: deep.mut.data.get() == t.mut.data.get() // The tensors share the same values!
deep.mut.data.get() !== t.mut.data.get() // ...but they are not the same array!

blocks.text: Both the copied tensor and its slice have the expected values.
We can use the following types and values for the above code.

expected: [true, false, true, false, true, false, true, false, true] as boolean[]
